title: Title II of The Americans With Disabilities Act Compliance
content:
Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA): Essential Compliance for State and Local Officials

I. Overview of Title II of the ADA

Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) mandates that state and local governments ensure individuals with disabilities have equal access to public services, programs, and activities. This applies to everything from public buildings and sidewalks to emergency services and digital communications.

Failure to comply can result in lawsuits, loss of federal funding, and public scrutiny, making ADA compliance a legal necessity and a moral obligation for state and local officials.

II. Critical Compliance Areas for Cities

1. ADA Coordinator: The City‚Äôs Compliance Officer

For cities with 50 or more employees, the ADA requires the designation of an ADA Coordinator to oversee compliance. This is one of the most crucial roles in ensuring accessibility.

Why an ADA Coordinator Is Essential:

‚Ä¢ Single Point of Contact ‚Äì Residents with disabilities need a clear, accessible official they can reach out to for concerns or accommodation requests.

‚Ä¢ Enforcement & Oversight ‚Äì The coordinator is responsible for identifying and removing barriers in public spaces, policies, and services.

‚Ä¢ Training & Education ‚Äì Ensuring city employees understand ADA requirements and how to properly interact with individuals with disabilities.

‚Ä¢ Preventing Legal Violations ‚Äì By proactively addressing issues, an ADA Coordinator helps avoid lawsuits, complaints, and federal intervention.

‚Ä¢ Transition Planning ‚Äì Cities must create and maintain an ADA Transition Plan, identifying barriers and laying out a timeline for removing them.

Without a designated ADA Coordinator, compliance can become disorganized and ineffective, putting the city at risk for violations.

2. Public Visibility: ADA-Compliant Signage

State and Local Officials must ensure that signs are clearly visible, properly placed, and ADA-compliant to help individuals with disabilities navigate public spaces.

Key Requirements for Signage:

‚Ä¢ Braille & Tactile Signs ‚Äì Public buildings, restrooms, and elevators must have signs in Braille and raised lettering for individuals with vision impairments.

‚Ä¢ Clear and High-Contrast Lettering ‚Äì Signs must be easy to read, with large fonts and high-contrast colors.

‚Ä¢ Directional and Informational Signage ‚Äì Clear directions to accessible entrances, exits, restrooms, and elevators should be posted in all city buildings.

‚Ä¢ Parking Signs ‚Äì Handicapped parking must be properly marked with internationally recognized accessibility symbols.

‚Ä¢ Emergency Signage ‚Äì Evacuation routes and emergency exits must be marked in accessible formats, including audible and visual alerts.

Failure to post proper signage creates barriers to access and can lead to ADA violations.

3. Automatic Door Openers: Ensuring Physical Access

One of the most essential but often overlooked ADA requirements is the presence of automatic door openers (push-button systems) at public buildings.

Why Automatic Door Openers Are Critical:

‚Ä¢ Necessary for Mobility-Impaired Individuals ‚Äì Many individuals use wheelchairs, walkers, crutches, or other assistive devices and cannot physically open heavy doors.

‚Ä¢ Required for Compliance ‚Äì ADA regulations mandate accessible doors with a clear width of at least 32 inches and a mechanism that allows easy opening.

‚Ä¢ Improves Accessibility for All ‚Äì Not just for people with disabilities‚Äîthese openers benefit elderly residents, parents with strollers, and individuals carrying heavy loads.

‚Ä¢ Prevents Legal Challenges ‚Äì Cities without properly functioning automatic door openers can face ADA complaints and lawsuits.

Cities Must Ensure That:

‚Ä¢ Automatic door buttons are installed at all public buildings.

‚Ä¢ The buttons are functional and regularly maintained‚Äîa broken automatic door violates ADA law.

‚Ä¢ Clear signage directs individuals to accessible entrances.

III. The Cost of Non-Compliance

Failing to adhere to Title II of the ADA can result in:

‚Ä¢ Lawsuits & DOJ Enforcement ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Justice actively enforces ADA compliance, leading to court orders, fines, and legal fees.

‚Ä¢ Loss of Federal Funding ‚Äì Many federal grants require compliance with accessibility laws.

‚Ä¢ Public Outrage & Media Scrutiny ‚Äì Discrimination against individuals with disabilities can damage a city‚Äôs reputation and trust.

IV. Conclusion: Why Cities Must Prioritize ADA Compliance

ADA compliance is not optional‚Äîit is a legal requirement. Ensuring accessibility improves quality of life, protects the city from legal and financial risk, and ensures that all residents can fully participate in public life.

State and local officials must take proactive steps by:

1. Appointing an ADA Coordinator to enforce compliance.

2. Installing visible, ADA-compliant signage for clear navigation.

3. Ensuring automatic door openers function properly at public facilities.

By making these efforts, a city not only fulfills its legal obligations but also creates a more inclusive and accessible community for all residents.

title: REQUIREMENT OF ADA COORDINATOR
content:
If a public entity has 50 or more employees, it is required to designate at least one responsible employee to coordinate ADA compliance.1 A government entity may elect to have more than one ADA Coordinator. Although the law does not refer to this person as an ‚ÄúADA Coordinator,‚Äù this term is commonly used in state and local governments across the country and will be used in this chapter.

¬†

The ADA Coordinator is responsible for coordinating the efforts of the government entity to comply with Title II and investigating any complaints that the entity has violated Title II. The name, office address, and telephone number of the ADA Coordinator must be provided to interested persons.

¬†

Common Question: Which employees count?

If a local government or other public entity has fewer than 50 employees, it is not required to appoint an ADA Coordinator or establish grievance procedures.

¬†

The number of employees is based on a government-wide total, including employees of each department, division, or other sub-unit. Both part-time and full-time employees count. Contractors are not counted as employees for determining the number of employees.

¬†

For example: Jones City has 30 full-time employees and 20 part-time employees. The employees include ten police department employees and eight fire department employees.

¬†

Jones City must have an ADA Coordinator and an ADA grievance procedure. The total number of employees is 50 because both full-time and part-time employees are counted. In addition, the police and fire departments are part of the city-wide employment pool, and the requirements for an ADA Coordinator and an ADA grievance procedure cover both of those departments.

¬†

Benefits of an ADA Coordinator

There are many benefits to having a knowledgeable ADA coordinator, even for smaller public entities that are not required to have one.

¬†

For members of the public, having an ADA Coordinator makes it easy to identify someone to help them with questions and concerns about disability discrimination. For example, the ADA Coordinator is often the main contact when someone wishes to request an auxiliary aid or service for effective communication, such as a sign language interpreter or documents in Braille. A knowledgeable ADA Coordinator will be able to efficiently assist people with disabilities with their questions. She or he will also be responsible for investigating complaints.

¬†

Having an ADA Coordinator also benefits state and local government entities. It provides a specific contact person with knowledge and information about the ADA so that questions by staff can be answered efficiently and consistently. In addition, she or he coordinates compliance measures and can be instrumental in ensuring that compliance plans move forward. With the help of this Tool Kit, ADA Coordinators can take the lead in auditing their state or local government‚Äôs programs, policies, activities, services, and facilities for ADA compliance.

¬†

An Effective ADA Coordinator

The regulations require state and local governments with 50 or more employees to designate an employee responsible for coordinating compliance with ADA requirements. Here are some of the qualifications that help an ADA Coordinator to be effective:

  • familiarity with the state or local government‚Äôs structure, activities, and employees
  • knowledge of the ADA and other laws addressing the rights of people with disabilities, such as Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. ¬ß 794
  • experience with people with a broad range of disabilities
  • knowledge of various alternative formats and alternative technologies that enable people with disabilities to communicate, participate, and perform tasks
  • ability to work cooperatively with the local government and people with disabilities
  • familiarity with any local disability advocacy groups or other disability groups
  • skills and training in negotiation and mediation
  • organizational and analytical skills

I am Matthew Reardon, an investigative journalist who runs the "We the People News" platform, and I am fighting back against the government's attempt to impose a sweeping gag order on my criminal case. I have respectfully opposed the government‚Äôs Motion for a Protective Order (Doc. 23) and the continuation of the Interim Protective Order (Doc. 24).

The government is trying to stop me‚Äîa journalist with over 3,000 subscribers‚Äîfrom possessing copies of or publicly discussing the evidence in my own criminal case. I believe this protective order is a continuation of the very suppression of speech that led to this prosecution.

My Fight for Transparency: This entire case arose because I engaged in constitutionally protected activities: documenting my interactions with federal law enforcement and protesting what I discovered‚Äîthrough a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request‚Äîwas unlawful surveillance (a BOLO alert) targeting my journalism.

I believe the materials the government now seeks to shield from public scrutiny are central to understanding their improper motivation and the retaliatory nature of this entire prosecution. They claim the documents are sensitive, but I have already lawfully published extensive records from the FOIA request, including communications between U.S. Marshals and courthouse staff, two days before my arrest on August 25, 2025. I also livestreamed the incident and have already published extensive video documentation on my YouTube channel, meaning much of the supposedly "sensitive" information is already public.

The government has failed to demonstrate "good cause" for imposing these sweeping restrictions, relying only on vague, generalized assertions about courthouse security. This case raises fundamental questions about First Amendment protection for journalists, government surveillance (BOLO alerts) against citizens, and how federal law enforcement responds to accountability journalism. The public has an overwhelming interest in transparency to ensure the government respects constitutional boundaries. I argue that I should not be gagged from discussing my own prosecution.

Galveston Tyrants Exposed (and a whole lot more)

On August 11, 2023, a routine drive across the causeway into Galveston turned into something far more sinister. Just after 2 a.m., investigative journalist and constitutional rights activist Matthew Reardon was pulled over by Galveston Police Department officers. Within minutes, what began as a traffic stop became a felony DWI investigation and arrest.

The officers claimed to smell alcohol. Reardon, who had not consumed a drop in years, immediately denied it and demanded a breathalyzer‚Äîthe most direct way to prove sobriety. Officers refused. Instead, I they pushed for field sobriety tests that he declined, citing their unreliability, and then arrested him anyway.

At the hospital, the refusal to administer a breathalyzer escalated to something darker: a forced blood draw. Nearly a dozen officers restrained him while he was handcuffed, puncturing his arm multiple times with needles. No warrant was shown. Toxicology results (PDF) later confirmed what Reardon had said all along: no alcohol in his system.

The arrest did not stop at Galveston‚Äôs borders. While in booking, Reardon overheard his arresting officer on the phone with Lafayette County, Mississippi Deputy Kandace Beavers‚Äîan officer who had previously testified against him in a 2021 DUI case now under appeal.

That case remains pending before the Mississippi Court of Appeals (Case No. 2024-KA-00839-COA). Crucial evidence in that trial ‚Äúdisappeared‚Äù before the court ever saw it. Less than a year later, it was Beavers‚Äô testimony in a separate, unrelated matter‚Äînow alleged and demonstrated as perjury‚Äîwhich sent Reardon to prison for a year.

On August 2, 2023, just one day after being released from prison, Reardon published a video expos√© showing undeniable proof that Beavers intentionally lied under oath to send him to prison. Her voice surfacing again just 9 days later on August 11, 2023. This time through a phone call to Galveston Police officer William Osteen, pointing now to something bigger, much bigger: a cross-state conspiracy to escalate charges and silence a critic.


The call recordings couldn‚Äôt be clearer. The FBI had an obligation and responsibility to intervene, by acknowledging communication with me, that I did exactly as I was advised in trying to report law enforcement corruption involving the Lafayette County Sheriff‚Äôs Department. Silence is complicity and in this case, culpability. They knew she lied and they chose to stay silent despite direct involvement. And because of their intent in not intervening and allowing such an unconscionable injustice to manifest, Beavers attacked again, and this time far worse. To this day, not a word out of the FBI. There is no question this is neglect to prevent. This nightmare has malicious intent all over it. Both by Beavers and the FBI. -Matthew Reardon


At the center of the Galveston arrest was Officer William Osteen. His body-worn camera footage captured him asking, within minutes of the stop: ‚ÄúYou an auditor man?‚Äù, telling one officer ‚Äúthis one‚Äôs an auditor, I got this one‚Äù, and then claiming to yet another officer that he could ‚Äúgo off slurred speech and the smell‚Äù to justify an arrest.

The record shows contradiction after contradiction. In his sworn affidavit, Osteen marked ‚Äúodor of alcoholic beverage on breath: moderate,‚Äù but later admitted he never smelled alcohol on Reardon‚Äôs breath. He testified to both ‚Äúdilated pupils‚Äù and ‚Äúpinpoint pupils‚Äù in separate hearings. And most damning, he falsely told the court that toxicology results showed alcohol in Reardon‚Äôs system when they did not.

On February 25, 2025, Reardon‚Äôs attorney, Ben Campagna, filed a Motion for Franks Hearing (PDF) ‚Äî a constitutional proceeding held when an officer inserts falsehoods or omits critical facts from a warrant application. If the lies are removed, there was never probable cause for the arrest.

This September, Reardon returned to Galveston‚Äînot in custody, but standing outside the police department with cameras rolling. His livestreams drew national attention, part of a broader push to hold the same officers accountable who once staged his arrest.

Federal Courthouse Arrest: First Amendment Under Attack

views October 1, 2025 8:00 am

In a shocking display of government overreach, independent journalist Matthew Reardon faces criminal charges for exercising his constitutional rights outside the John M. Shaw Federal Courthouse in Lafayette, Louisiana. As the founder of We the People News, I've been following this case closely, as it represents a direct assault on press freedom and the right to petition the government for redress of grievances.

Court documents reveal a disturbing pattern of surveillance targeting Reardon after he discovered through a Freedom of Information Act request that U.S. Marshals had placed a BOLO ("Be On the Lookout") alert on him simply for engaging in protected journalistic activities. Rather than addressing this concerning violation of press freedoms, federal authorities doubled down by arresting Reardon when he peacefully protested this surveillance on August 25, 2025.

The facts are clear: Reardon was conducting a constitutionally protected protest on the courthouse steps, a traditional public forum where First Amendment activities have historically received the highest level of protection. His protest signs criticized what he perceived as unlawful targeting of his journalism through the BOLO alert.

When Marshal Hayden Nugent invited Reardon inside the courthouse only to immediately threaten him with arrest for recording, Reardon peacefully exited the building. Despite complying with all directives and maintaining a peaceful demeanor throughout the encounter, Reardon was ultimately arrested when Marshal Nugent forcibly seized his camera equipment.

Reardon's defense team has filed a powerful motion to dismiss, citing binding Supreme Court precedent that clearly protects political protest in traditional public forums. The motion references Edwards v. South Carolina (1963), where the Supreme Court protected protesters who engaged in "boisterous, loud, and flamboyant conduct" while expressing political grievances.

The defense motion also cites United States v. Hylton, where the Fifth Circuit affirmed that criminal sanctions cannot be imposed for the "legitimate and protected exercise of the right to petition for the redress of grievances."

The government's opposition filing reveals the weakness of their case. They attempt to redefine courthouse steps‚Äîlong recognized as traditional public forums‚Äîas "nonpublic forums" to justify their censorship. This directly contradicts Supreme Court precedent in United States v. Grace (1983), which established that "the public sidewalks forming the perimeter of the Supreme Court grounds... are public forums and should be treated as such for First Amendment purposes."

Even more troubling, the government admits they cannot address Reardon's as-applied constitutional challenge before trial, essentially acknowledging they need to put him through the ordeal of criminal proceedings before addressing the fundamental constitutional issues at stake.

The government's prosecution targets three forms of constitutionally protected expression:

Political Speech: Reardon's protest signs and spoken commentary criticizing government surveillance fall within "the very center of the constitutionally protected area of free expression" according to Supreme Court precedent.

Press Activity: As an investigative journalist documenting events for his 3,000-subscriber YouTube channel, Reardon's recording activities are protected under the First Amendment's press clause.

Petition for Redress: Reardon's expression of grievances against government officials constitutes petitioning for redress, which the Supreme Court has called "among the most precious of the liberties safeguarded by the Bill of Rights."

Perhaps most disturbing is the evidence of content-based discrimination. Reardon was targeted not because of any genuine disruption‚Äîthe defense motion notes that "members of the public continued to enter and exit the courthouse during his protest without incident"‚Äîbut because of the critical content of his message about federal law enforcement.

The government's claim that Reardon obstructed an entrance falls apart when examining the facts: he placed his camera near a door that was permanently locked to public access, meaning there was no "usual use" to obstruct. When asked to move the camera, Reardon immediately complied, demonstrating his respect for legitimate security concerns.

This case represents a dangerous precedent for independent journalists and citizens who dare to criticize government actions. If peaceful protest on courthouse steps‚Äîa location specifically recognized by the Supreme Court as a traditional public forum‚Äîcan be criminalized, then the First Amendment protections we all rely on are in grave danger.

As this case proceeds, We the People News will monitor developments and fight for the constitutional rights that protect all Americans' ability to hold their government accountable. See my Linktree at https://www.linktree.com/wtpnews for important links #1A #civilrights ...
